story.title: The Christmas Sweater - Episode 5
story.storyDescription: Ever since her mother’s death, Noelle hasn’t wanted to go home for the holidays. But perhaps a bit of holiday magic is all she needs…
story.creator: web-uploader
story.prePaywallNotification: Noelle is about to be floored by Beatrice’s story, which involved THE CHRISTMAS SWEATER. Read it in the next episode.
story.postPaywallNotification: Is THE CHRISTMAS SWEATER truly magical? 🎄✨ Read the rest of the story to find out.

messages.text: Wearing the magical sweater, Noelle walks out of the house and shuts the door behind her.
The playful ring of the jingle bells on her family’s wreath puts a spring in her step as she heads into town.
She makes a pit stop at her favorite café for a sweet gingerbread latte…
And is stopped in her tracks by the sight of a familiar face.
Are you here to steal my eggnog again?
What?! What are you doing here?
Visiting my aunt. This is where I’m celebrating the holidays this year.
Really? Me too. I grew up in this town.
No kidding!
Lawrence flashes her his trademark devilish grin.
And Noelle feels herself melt all over again.
So as a kid, did you need alone time during the holidays too?
Noelle tilts her head.
Actually, no. When I was younger, I was the queen of the holidays in my house.
Her smile bursts free at the memory.
Oh yeah?
He glances at her sweater.
Well, I’m happy to see your holiday spirit coming back.
The two lock eyes for a minute and Noelle feels the ground fall out beneath her feet.
Lawrence’s irises are impossibly green.
So…what does the queen of the holidays do?
She’s in charge of everything — the decorating, the baking, the dinner menus…
Lawrence raises his eyebrows and smiles.
I didn’t realize there were multiple dinner menus.
Noelle can’t stop smiling.
Then you haven’t truly celebrated the holidays.
You HAVE to plan multiple menus.
Otherwise, you could end up with something terrible like canned cranberry sauce.
I happen to like canned cranberry sauce.
No one likes canned cranberry sauce after they’ve tried my homemade stuff.
Lawrence holds Noelle’s gaze for another heated moment.
Then his eyes drop down to her mouth. His tongue swipes across his lower lip.
When he finds his voice, it comes out deep and husky.
I guess I’ll have to try it then.
Desire fills Noelle’s entire body — she can hardly speak.
After a few false starts, she finally forms a coherent sentence.
I — um, I should probably get my latte and get going.
There’s someone I need to see.
Noelle ducks her head and turns toward the counter.
But she doesn’t even take two steps before a large, warm hand encircles her own.
Noelle turns around, and looks into Lawrence’s earnest eyes.
Come to dinner with me tonight?
Please?
I know you like your alone time at the holidays, but I think—
Yes.
What?
I’d love to have dinner with you. Yes.
An image of her favorite restaurant, the cozy and romantic Wellington Room, flashes through her head.
And I know just the place.
Well, since this is my first time in Portsmouth…
I’m glad you’re taking the lead, Christmas Queen.
Noelle laughs.
You won’t regret it.
Then, almost twenty-four hours after meeting him…
Noelle finally gives Lawrence her number.
She tries not to skip as she walks up to the counter, grabs her latte, and strides out the door.
Maybe…just maybe…this Christmas sweater is magical after all.
Smiling, she strolls down the street, stopping to leave money for the Salvation Army Santa.
And then she enters Beatrice’s quaint shop.
For the first time since childhood, she sees it for the wonder that it is…
Floor to ceiling cedar bookshelves line the walls, chock-full of all of Noelle’s favorite stories.
Perhaps she and Beatrice have something in common after all…
Good morning, Beatrice.
I came to apologize for yesterday.
Oh, honey! You don’t have to—
No, really. I’m an adult and I was acting like a child.
I heard the good news about you and my dad and…
I think it’s great.
Beatrice places the stack of books she’s holding on the counter.
They hit the hard wood with a distinguished smack.
Let’s sit in the leather chairs, okay?
I’ve been wanting to have a proper chit-chat with you.
She points to the best reading seats in the shop.
Noelle smiles, remembering the times she and Maria used to cozy into one oversized chair together…
Even when there were two seats free.
She and her sister just always wanted to be next to each other.
Beatrice flips the “Open” sign to “Closed” and then joins Noelle.
I think this conversation warrants no distractions.
Noelle smiles.
I think you might be right.
I’m so sorry for the way I spoke to you.
Beatrice takes Noelle’s hands.
For the first time in five years, Noelle doesn’t shirk away from her touch.
Thank you, dear.
I forgive you.
Noelle sighs. She feels a weight lift off her chest.
As much as I appreciate that you’re opening up to the idea of your father and me together…
I know that you won’t just be able to accept it overnight.
Beatrice pats Noelle’s hands gently…
And Noelle feels her tense shoulders relax.
Thanks Beatrice. I really want to be ready to see you and my dad together, but I…
I just loved my mom so much.
I did too.
That’s why it took me such a long time to even consider a relationship with your father.
What?! But you guys got together only one year after my Mom’s death!
Yes, but a year is a long time for two old folks like us.
Dating at this age is different. It’s easier to know what you want.
And, especially in your father’s case, what you need.
Noelle tries to hide the confusion on her face.
I can see that I’m not being very clear.
Let me step back.
It all starts with a story about the sweater you’re wearing.
This sweater?
Yes. That sweater used to belong to your mother.
